Description: The lower part of a hollow terracotta standing figure, very likely to be a woman, the feet close together on a minimal plinth. She is draped, the lower clothing curving in near the feet, and there is an over-garment with two long dangling tassels in the front. At the figure's left side is a long feature, perhaps part of the clothing: there may have been a symmetrical arrangement on the right side, but it is broken away. The back is plain. Two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt. Overall white dressing.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Excavation no. Mik/15. Purchased: Oxford University Excavations at Faras in 1910-11: 'from the ruins of a Meroitic house of the Roman period'. This house, later in the excavations called the Western Palace, is described and illustrated in Griffith 1926: 21–3 and pls xii–xiv; its position on the site is shown on plans in Griffith 1921: pl. i; 1924: pl. xiv and 1927: pl. lxx. Roman period, first or second century AD. Comparandum: Near: Petrie 1905: pl. li:114, from House N at Ehnasiya, dated about third century AD or earlier.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3164)
